title: Victoria, NSW take steps to improve building industries
text:
Victoria's commercial and residential property industries could save up to $600 million a year by speeding up approval processes and eliminating duplications, according to a state government discussion paper.

Red Tape Commissioner Anna Cronin said planning and building delays and bottlenecks, the shortage of building surveyors and other building practitioners, and the overlap between the planning and building regulatory regimes create delays that cost commercial high-rise developments as much as $50,000 a day and add $70 a day to the cost of a low-rise housing development.

Fewer mix-ups: Victoria and NSW are both taking steps to improve their building industries. Michele Mossop

The paper kicks off a consultation by proposing improvements to council and referral authority processes through early engagement with applicants, removing duplicate requests for information and delivering better response times from the many decision-makers along the planning approvals pipeline. It will feed into an overhaul of the state's Building Act.

"The proposed improvements focus on eliminating bottlenecks, removing unnecessary steps and making sure approvals processes are as efficient and effective as possible," Ms Cronin said.

"They are practical and implementable and will reduce delays and costs."
description: Victoria is looking to cut bottlenecks and duplication, while NSW has introduced laws to boost accountability.
